title: 2  Litterature Review
text:
2.1 Introduction
Identity economics is a young field in the discipline. It was introduced and formalized by the work of Akerlof and Kranton.
The main idea of this field is to consider that people’s identity (defined as “A person’s sense of self) influences people’s behavior and therefore has socio-economic repercussions.
Traditional economic models struggle to fully explain phenomena, and the introduction of identity as an explanatory variable for individual choices provides some explanations.

title: 2  Litterature Review
text:
Note



Un papier très intéressant a notamment montré que l’identité influençait les performances. Une expérience sur des étudiantes asiatiques réalisant des tests de mathématiques a montré que lorsque leur identité asiatique était mise en avant, elle performaient mieux aux tests de mathématiques (relativement à lorsque c’est leur identité de genre qui était activée)
Le poids des stéréotypes semble donc important.









Note



Exemples concrets (économie de l’éducation)

title: 2  Litterature Review
text:
2.2 Model Elements
Identity economics proposes introducing the notion of identity (here understood as social identity) into the utility function.
The utility function \(U_j\) for individual \(j\) is given by:
\(U_j = U_j(a_j, a_j I_j)\)
Where

\(a_j\) represents the actions of individual \(j\) ,
\(a_j I_j\) captures the interaction between \(j\)’s actions and their identity \(I_j\).

Identity Function:
The identity function \(I_j\) depends on several factors:
\(I_j = I_j(a_j, a_{-j}, c_j, E_j, P)\)
Where:

\(a_j\) represents the actions of individual \(j\),
\(a_{-j}\) represents the actions of others,
\(c_j\) is the social category to which \(j\) belongs,
\(E_j\) are \(j\)’s given characteristics,
\(P\) are the prescriptions (social norms) associated with the category \(c_j\).

title: 2  Litterature Review
text:
2.3 Issues Addressed






Note



La recherche en économie de l’identité a pris plusieurs directions:

Identité et préférences sociales: méthodologie = économie expérimentale
Identité et fragmentation, conflits
Mesures de l’identité?
variables catégorielles ; souvent binaires
Mesures continues de l’identité? Comment capturer une certaine distance aux normes?











Connected papers’ graph

title: 3  Gender Identity Index
text:
3.1 Introduction
This document describes the steps involved in creating a continuous gender measurement index, based on the cultural practices of the French in 2018 (Enquête sur les Pratiques Culturelles, 2018).
\[I_{1j} = \sum_{k=1}^{Z} w_{1k} \cdot X_{k j}\]
In this expression, \(I_{1j}\) denotes the index for individual \(j\), while \(w_{1k}\) represents the weight associated with each cultural variable \(X_{kj}\). The summation encompasses all \(Z\) cultural variables, allowing us to capture the overall cultural engagement of the individual.

text: Work In Progress

title: 3  Gender Identity Index
text:
3.7 MCA
Since our data are binary (1 if the activity is practiced; 0 otherwise), we will carry out a MCA to determine whether gender is an important dimension in cultural practices and define the weight of each variable.
Pour plus d’informations sur l’ACM vous référez à ce lien


Show the code
pratiques_cols_1 <- c( "Knitting" , 
                     "Cards_games",  
                     "Gambling" , 
                     "Cooking" , 
                     "DIY"  ,
                     "Vegetable_garden" , 
                     "Fishing_hunting" , 
                     "Collection"  ,
                     "Vehicle_custom",
                     "Making_music"   ,
                     "Diary" ,
                     "Writing" ,  
                     "Painting",  
                     "Montage"  , 
                     "Pottery" , 
                     "Theater" , 
                     "Drawing" , 
                     "Dancing",  
                     "Photography"  ,
                     "Genealogy" , 
                     "Science"  ,
                     "None" ,
                     "Video_games"  ,
                     "Library"  ,
                     "Concert"
                            )


#MCA

# Ajouter la colonne `sexe` à la sélection
cols_of_interest_1 <- c("Sex", "AGE", pratiques_cols_1)

# Créer une nouvelle dataframe avec ces colonnes
data_pratiques <- my_data_frame[, cols_of_interest_1]
data_pratiques$AGE <- cut(data_pratiques$AGE, 
                          breaks = quantile(data_pratiques$AGE, probs = seq(0, 1, 0.25), na.rm = TRUE), 
                          include.lowest = TRUE)
ra_data <- na.omit(data_pratiques)

cols_to_factor <- c(  "Knitting" , 
                      "Cards_games",  
                      "Gambling" , 
                      "Cooking" , 
                      "DIY"  ,
                      "Vegetable_garden" , 
                      "Fishing_hunting" , 
                      "Collection"  ,
                      "Vehicle_custom",
                      "Making_music"   ,
                      "Diary" ,
                      "Writing" ,  
                      "Painting",  
                      "Montage"  , 
                      "Pottery" , 
                      "Theater" , 
                      "Drawing" , 
                      "Dancing",  
                      "Photography"  ,
                      "Genealogy" , 
                      "Science"  ,
                      "None"  ,
                      "Video_games"  ,
                      "Library"  ,
                      "Concert")

# Appliquer as.factor à ces colonnes
ra_data[cols_to_factor] <- lapply(ra_data[cols_to_factor], as.factor)


acm2_fm <- ra_data |> 
  FactoMineR::MCA(
    ncp = Inf,
    graph = TRUE,
    quali.sup = 1:2
  )























Show the code
explor(acm2_fm)

title: 3  Gender Identity Index
text:
3.9 Building The Index


Show the code
# Initialiser un vecteur pour stocker l'indice de chaque individu
ra_data$indice_culturel <- 0

# Parcourir chaque individu
for (i in 1:nrow(ra_data)) {
  
  # Initialiser l'indice de l'individu à 0
  indice_individu <- 0
  
  # Parcourir chaque colonne de pratiques (les colonnes de 3 à 11)
  for (pratique in 3:27) {
    
    # Récupérer la réponse de l'individu pour cette pratique (0 ou 1)
    reponse <- ra_data[i, pratique]
    
    # Si la réponse est 1, ajouter la coordonnée de la modalité correspondante à l'indice
    if (reponse == 1) {
      
      # Créer le nom de la modalité (par exemple "knitting_1" ou "knitting_0")
      nom_modalite_1 <- paste0(names(ra_data)[pratique], "_1")
      nom_modalite_0 <- paste0(names(ra_data)[pratique], "_0")
      
      # Trouver la coordonnée associée à la modalité correspondante
      if (nom_modalite_1 %in% modalites_coord$Modalite) {
        indice_individu <- indice_individu + modalites_coord$Coord_Dim2[modalites_coord$Modalite == nom_modalite_1]
      }
      if (nom_modalite_0 %in% modalites_coord$Modalite) {
        indice_individu <- indice_individu + modalites_coord$Coord_Dim2[modalites_coord$Modalite == nom_modalite_0]
      }
    }
  }
  
  # Assigner l'indice calculé à l'individu
  ra_data$indice_culturel[i] <- indice_individu
}
####Normalisation

# Calculer les valeurs minimum et maximum de l'indice
min_indice <- min(ra_data$indice_culturel, na.rm = TRUE)
max_indice <- max(ra_data$indice_culturel, na.rm = TRUE)

# Normaliser l'indice
ra_data$indice_culturel_normalise <- (ra_data$indice_culturel - min_indice) / (max_indice - min_indice)

# Vérifier le résultat
head(ra_data[, c("indice_culturel", "indice_culturel_normalise")])


  indice_culturel indice_culturel_normalise
1       2.8024423                 0.8624142
2       0.5427446                 0.5073268
3      -0.4557477                 0.3504244
4      -0.3429253                 0.3681533
5       0.0409659                 0.4284777
6      -0.2367887                 0.3848315

title: 3  Gender Identity Index
text:
3.10 Index Descriptive Satistics


Show the code
data$identity<-ra_data$indice_culturel_normalise
data$indice<-ra_data$indice_culturel
ggplot(data, aes(x = identity, fill = Sex)) +
  geom_density(alpha = 0.5) +
  scale_fill_manual(values = c("blue", "pink")) + # Palette de couleurs "fancy"
  labs(title = "Density of The Normalized Cultural Index by Sexe",
       x = "Normalized Cultural Index",
       y = "Density",
       fill = "Sexe") +
  theme_minimal()

  tbl_summary(include=c("identity"),by = "Sex"

title: 3  Gender Identity Index
text:
3.11 Conformity (Distance To Norms)


Show the code
mean_gender <- tapply(data$identity, data$Sex, mean)
sd_gender <- tapply(data$identity, data$Sex, sd)

data$distance<- (data$identity - mean_gender[data$Sex]) / sd_gender[data$Sex]

ggplot(data, aes(x = distance, color = Sex, fill = Sex)) +
  geom_density(alpha = 0.4) +
  labs(title = "Density of Distance to the Norm, by Sex", 
       x = "Distance to the Norm (Z-score)", y = "Density") +
  scale_fill_manual(values = c("blue", "pink")) +
  scale_color_manual(values = c("blue", "pink")) +
  theme_minimal()

title: Research: IDnomics
text:
About
My research focuses on the economics of identity.
My thesis focused on the phenomena of urban segregation, i.e. the social and spatial isolation of different groups of individuals.
My current work focuses on the measurement of gender identity and the socio-economic repercussions of gender inequalities.

title: Research: IDnomics
text:
IDnomics

Presentation
IDnomics offers a collection of tools for identity economists. First, I present this stream of research through a review of the existing literature. Next, I propose an identity measurement tool. Other research projects may follow….

text:
